Fact: Once thought to be a dinosaur relative, it is now considered one of the closest known non‑pterosaur ancestors based on ankle and inner‑ear anatomy.
Dimorphodon shows early Jurassic pterosaur diversity; its short wings and longer back legs allowed it to thrive in an arboreal environment.
Long considered a Pterodactylus, it had a distinctive tail vane.

column6: taking an ecological role similar to modern-day nightjars; its reconstruction is heavily informed by the related Jeholopterus."

Fact: Juveniles resemble Ctenochasma, leading to many misassigned specimens.
Guidraco used its long conical teeth to catch fish in shallow Jurassic waters. It may belong to Anhanguerinae based on skull and tooth structure.
An iconic and recognizable species, both Pteranodon and Nyctosaurus were discovered by Marsh and originally lumped into Pterodactylus.
A very small azhdarchoid, possibly the juvenile form of Sinopterus. If it is its own species, it would be the smallest known pterosaur.
Quetzalcoatlus lived at the very end of the dinosaurs’ reign. It was one of the largest pterosaurs, greatly capable of both aerial and terrestrial movement.
